\n<\/p><\/div>"} Go to Resize and change the width and height to 150 each.
Now you have a smaller working space!
Click the magnifying glass tool, then click on the blank white space.
The white space should be bigger.
Click on the magnifying glass again, and then click 8x.
The white space now covers the whole paint screen.
Click on the pencil and select desired color (At the bottom of the screen).
Start with a light color, as we are going to shade.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b5\/Make-Simple-Pixels-in-Microsoft-Paint-Step-5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b5\/Make-Simple-Pixels-in-Microsoft-Paint-Step-5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Start drawing the outline of your pixel.
Mine is an apple, so I'll start with the apple.
It's pink!
Then, color the inside the same color.
Add the stems and leaves.
Now, you done the base apple.
It's time for shading!
Pick two or three more darker colors then the base color (pink).
After choosing 2-3 different colors, it's time to shade!
Starting from the lightest to the darkest, in the apple, draw thick lines that follow the shape of the apple.
The result will be better than plain, non-shaded one!
Still using the pencil.
This is what I got: Almost done!
I added a small highlight to make it look nicer.
Here is what I got at the end, including the colors I used.
Zoom out.
To do this, Click on the View, then click on Zoom out.
Admire your pixel!

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Using the dotted rectangle tool, outline your pixel by clicking near your pixel, and dragging until your pixel is fully inside the box.
Then, move your pixel to the top left corner of the white space, but leave little space, so your pixel won't be cut.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a0\/Make-Simple-Pixels-in-Microsoft-Paint-Step-12.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a0\/Make-Simple-Pixels-in-Microsoft-Paint-Step-12.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

Then, let go of your mouse.
All is left would be just your pixel and a little white space.
